{{Distinguish|Kovilj Monastery}} {{Infobox monastery | name = Kovilje monastery | image = Kovilje.jpg | caption = The Monastery of Kovilje | full = Манастир Ковиљe | other_names = | order = [[Serbian Orthodox]] | established = 12th century
Renovated 1644 | disestablished = | mother = | diocese = [[Žiča]] Diocese | churches = * Cave-church of Archangel Gabriel * Church of St. Nicholas | founder = [[Saint Sava]] | dedication = Archangel Gabriel | people = Archbishop [[Gavrilo Rašković]] | map_type = Serbia | map_caption = Location of Kovilje Monastery within Serbia | location = [[Kovilje]], [[Ivanjica]], [[Serbia]] | coord = | oscoor = | remains = | public_access = }} '''Kovilje Monastery''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Манастир Ковиљe}}), dedicated to [[Archangel Gabriel]], is a [[monastery]] of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]], located in the village of [[Kovilje]], in the municipality of [[Ivanjica]], in south-west [[Serbia]] belonging to the [[Žiča]] Diocese. It is sited between [[Golija]] and [[Javor (Serbia)|Javor]] mountains, in the [[Nošnica]] river valley. The monastery has two churches, one built partly in a [[cave]] and dedicated to the Archangel Gabriel, the other, added later, dedicated to [[St. Nicholas]]. The monastery was founded in the 12th century. The first written reference to it is in 1606, in the "''Kruševačkom Pomeniku''". It was rebuilt in 1644 by Archbishop Gavrilo (Rašković). Records from 1733 mention it as an educational establishment.{{Cite web |url= http://www.ivanjica.gov.rs/|title= Official website of municipality of Ivanjica|accessdate=9 May 2014 |work= |publisher= |date=}} The [[hegumen]] of the monastery is the young [[Serbian Orthodox]] Hieromonk Amvrosije. He lives there by himself with his tamed animals of two wolves, a fox, an eagle, a snake, raven, rabbit and an owl. The Serb-American community of [[Libertyville, Illinois|Libertyville]] have donated a motorcycle and 4-wheel-drive to the monastery. The life of the monastery has been documented in the Serbian documentary "Monah i vuk". ==Architecture== The monastery consists of two temples: the first is dedicated to the Holy [[Archangel Gabriel]] and another, that was later built, is dedicated to [[St. Nicholas]]. Church of the Holy Archangel partially rests on the rock, so it can be classified in a group of ascetic cave churches. It is a single building with [[altar]] niche. It is believed to have been built in the late 12th or the early 13th century, judging by the remains of frescoes and traditions. Another temple has a rectangular base and a [[dome]]. From frescoes dating from the 13th century, which have survived only in fragments, characters of saints are still well preserved.{{Cite web |url= http://www.ivatourism.org/|title= Tourist organisation of Ivanjica |accessdate=9 May 2014 |work= |publisher= |date=}} ==Restoration== During the year 1644, Metropolitan of Raska, Gavrilo(Rašković), visits the monastery and finds it extremely neglected, in serious condition. Then he restores it and stays in it for a while, and in 1651 he endows the Monastery with a shackled and decorated Holy Gospel for the liturgical needs of the restored church of St. Nicholas, and frees the monastery land, which was returned to the [[monastery]]. From the records of 1733,we find that a spiritualist Filip lives in the monastery, who taught those who wanted to become priests. From all this, the monastery was highly ranked as an important place in both spiritual, as well as in national and political life of the people of this region. One of the oldest schools in [[Serbia]] was open here in 1867. There was also a school for future priests. Since 1813, the monastery performed an active function of a regular parochial school. The monastery was restored in 2005, and the monastery refectory was built during 2007–2009. ==Gallery==
File:08-Manastir Kovilje 02.jpg|''Kovilje Monastery'' File:08-Manastir Kovilje 09.jpg|''The interior of the Church of Holy Archangel Gabriel'' File:08-Manastir Kovilje 16.jpg|''The icon of Christ in the Church of Holy Archangel Gabriel'' File:08-Manastir Kovilje 17.jpg|''The interior of the Church of St. Nicholas''

[[Baja California Sur]] state,
[[Mexico]] | metric-elev = | elevation-f = 374 | elevation-m = 114 | coordinates = {{Coord|23|09|06|N|109|43|15|W|region:MX-BCS_type:airport|display=inline,title}} | website = {{URL|http://www.loscabos-airport.com/}} | pushpin_map = Baja California Sur#Mexico | pushpin_mapsize = 250 | pushpin_label = SJD | metric-rwy = yes | r1-number = 16/34 | r1-length-f = 9843 | r1-length-m = 3000 | r1-surface = [[Asphalt]] | stat-year = 2017 | stat1-header = Total Passengers | stat1-data = 4,909,700 {{increase}} 15.6% | stat2-header = Ranking in Mexico | stat2-data = 6th {{steady}} | footnotes = Source: Grupo Aeroportuario del Pacífico }} '''Los Cabos International Airport''' {{Airport codes|SJD|MMSD}} is the [[List of the busiest airports in Mexico|sixth-busiest airport in Mexico]], located at [[San José del Cabo]] in [[Los Cabos Municipality]], [[Baja California Sur]] state, [[Mexico]]. The airport serves [[San José del Cabo]], [[Cabo San Lucas]], and the [[Los Cabos Municipality|Los Cabos area]]. ==History== From September 2011 until January 2012, the airport temporarily gained nonstop service to [[Asia]] with flights to [[Shanghai]], [[China]]. The airport handled 4,248,000 passengers in 2016, and 4,909,700 in 2017. It has become the most important airport in the state of [[Baja California Sur]]. Because of a dramatic increase in the number of holiday resorts and due to the region's fast population growth, the infrastructure of the airport is now insufficient compared to the increasing demand, causing a lack of available positions for aircraft during peak-hours, as in many other airports in Mexico. On September 15, 2014, Los Cabos International Airport was badly damaged by [[Hurricane Odile (2014)|Hurricane Odile]]. Planes were knocked against structures due to the winds from Odile. Many people went to the airport, demanding flights out of Cabo San Lucas. The [[Politics of Mexico|Mexican government]] began airlifting the first of thousands of stranded tourists, free of charge, to airports in Tijuana, Mazatlan, Guadalajara and Mexico City to catch connecting flights and, in the case of foreigners, receive consular assistance.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/16/hurricane-odile-mexico-airlifts-tourists-stranded |title=Hurricane Odile: Mexico begins airlifts of tourists stranded in Los Cabos |publisher=The Guardian |date=September 2014 |accessdate=January 21, 2017}} == Architecture == The architect of Los Cabos International Airport's 1997 renovation and expansion was Mexican architect and great-grandson of [[Queen Isabella II]] of Spain, Manuel De Santiago-de Borbón González Bravo. He was a member of [[International Council on Monuments and Sites|ICOMOS (International Council on Monuments and Sites)]], and his lifetime architectural legacy to Mexico adds to {{convert|11000000|m2}} built nationwide, including famous buildings and national sites, as well as important national restorations like the Mexican Houses of Congress Palace ([[Palacio Legislativo de San Lázaro]]). ==Terminals== [[File:Los Cabos International Airport, 25 March 2013.jpg|thumbnail|The name of the airport displayed over the exit of the international arrivals exit terminal.]] [[Image:AeropuertoSJD 01.JPG|thumb|Terminal 2.]] [[Image:Aeromexico Boeing 767-300ER at Los Cabos International Airport.jpg|right|thumb|[[Aeroméxico]] [[Boeing 767-300]] at Terminal 1]] [[Image:AAinCabo.JPG|thumb|American Airlines plane, after a flight from [[Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport]].]] [[Image:San Jose del Cabo Airport Terminals.jpg|right|thumb|Terminal Layout (After T4 is completed)]] [[Image:Pista 16 SJD.jpg|thumb|Airport's Runway.]] [[Image:Los Cabos International Airport tower.jpg|thumb|Airport's Control Tower.]] [[Image:AeropuertoSJD 02.JPG|thumb|Restaurants and stores at Terminal.]] The airport has two terminals. Terminal 1 operates domestic flights, and Terminal 2 operates international flights. ==Airlines and destinations== ===Passenger=== {{Airport destination list | [[Aeroméxico]] | [[Mexico City International Airport|Mexico City]] | {{nowrap|[[Aeroméxico Connect]]}} | [[Mexico City International Airport|Mexico City]] | [[Aero Pacífico]] | [[Culiacán International Airport|Culiacán]], [[Los Mochis International Airport|Los Mochis]] | [[Air Canada]] | '''Seasonal''': [[Calgary International Airport|Calgary]], [[Vancouver International Airport|Vancouver]] | [[Air Canada Rouge]] | '''Seasonal''': [[Toronto Pearson International Airport|Toronto–Pearson]] | [[Alaska Airlines]] | [[Los Angeles International Airport|Los Angeles]], [[John Wayne Airport|Orange County]], [[San Diego International Airport|San Diego]], [[San Francisco International Airport|San Francisco]], [[San Jose International Airport|San Jose (CA)]]

revision.text:
The '''''Northern Rhodesia Government Gazette''''' was the [[government gazette]] of [[Northern Rhodesia]].
The ''Gazette'' replaced the ''[[North-Eastern Rhodesia Gazette]]'' when [[North-Eastern Rhodesia|North-Eastern]] and [[North-Western Rhodesia]] were merged into Northern Rhodesia. There was no gazette for North-Western Rhodesia.<ref name=roberts/>
The ''Gazette'' was published by the [[British South Africa Company]] from 1911<ref name="Meebelo1971">{{cite book|author=Meebelo, Henry S.|title=Reaction to Colonialism: A Prelude to the Politics of Independence in Northern Zambia 1893-1939|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TwPpAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA292|date= 1971|publisher=Manchester: [[Manchester University Press]]|isbn=978-0-7190-1029-3|pages=292}}</ref> until it was taken over by the Colonial Office in 1924 when they assumed responsibility for Northern Rhodesia.<ref name=roberts>"Government ''Gazettes'' for Northern Rhodesia" by Andrew Roberts in ''[[History in Africa]]'', Vol. 16 (1989), pp. 397-400.</ref> It continued until independence in 1964 when it was replaced by the Zambian government gazette.<ref>[http://www.crl.edu/collections/topics/official-gazettes/search?titleID=t472&pc=1 NORTHERN RHODESIA (BRITISH PROTECTORATE)] CRL Foreign Official Gazette Database, 2014. Retrieved 16 May 2014. [https://www.webcitation.org/6PcWy90AP Archived here.]</ref>
==See also== *[[List of British colonial gazettes]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Italic title}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Government gazettes|Rhodesia]] [[Category:Publications established in 1911]] [[Category:British South Africa Company]] [[Category:Northern Rhodesia]] [[Category:1911 establishments in Northern Rhodesia]] [[Category:Publications disestablished in 1964]] [[Category:1964 disestablishments in Northern Rhodesia]] {{Africa-newspaper-stub}} [[Category:Newspapers published in Zambia]]

'''Portuguese animation''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]: ''Animação portuguesa'') is [[animation]] created in [[Portugal]] or by [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] [[animators]].
==History== In 2013, ''[[Kali, o pequeno vampiro]]'' won the award for [[Sophia Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]] at the [[2013 Sophia Awards]]. In 2014, ''[[O gigante]]'' was nominated for [[Goya Award for Best Animated Short Film|Best Animated Short Film]] at the [[28th Goya Awards]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.publico.pt/culturaipsilon/noticia/animacao-portuguesa-candidata-aos-premios-de-cinema-goya-1622996|title= Animação portuguesa candidata aos prémios de cinema Goya|author= [[Lusa news agency]]|date= 9 February 2014|accessdate= 28 July 2014|work= [[publico.pt]]|language= Portuguese}}</ref>
==Animators== * [[João Fazenda]] * [[Abi Feijó]] * [[Isabel Aboim Inglez]] * [[Regina Pessoa]] * [[Cláudio Sá]]
==Awards== * [[Sophia Award for Best Animated Short Film]]
==Festivals== * [[Cinanima]] * [[Monstra (festival)|Monstra]]
==Works== *''[[Midsummer Dream]]'' *''[[Até ao tecto do mundo]]''<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.dn.pt/inicio/artes/interior.aspx?content_id=2181317&seccao=Cinema|title= "Até ao tecto do mundo" distinguido nos EUA|author= [[Lusa news agency]]|date= 13 December 2011|accessdate= 28 July 2014|work= dn.pt|language= Portuguese}}</ref> *''[[Do céu e da terra]]'' *''[[Tragic Story with Happy Ending]]'' *''[[Kali, o pequeno vampiro]]'' *''[[Lágrimas de um palhaço]]'' *''[[Sem querer]]'' *''[[Nutri Ventures – The Quest for the 7 Kingdoms]]'' *''[[O gigante]]''

{{About|the proposed Independent state||Lakota (disambiguation){{!}}Lakota}} {{Infobox country |conventional_long_name = Republic of Lakotah |native_name = |common_name = |image_flag = Pine Ridge Flag.svg |image_coat = |symbol_type = National emblem |image_map = Possible Lakotah borders.png |map_caption = Proposed location of Lakotah |national_motto =
{{native name|lkt|[[Mitakuye Oyasin|Mitaku Oyasin]]}}
We are all related |national_anthem = |official_languages = |capital = [[Porcupine, South Dakota|Porcupine]] (proclaimed) |largest_city = [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]] |government_type = {{nowrap|[[Matriarchy|Matriarchal]] [[confederation]] {{small|(proposed)}}}} |leader_title1 = |leader_name1 = |area_magnitude = |area_km2 = 200,000 |area_sq_mi = 77,220 |percent_water = |population_estimate = |population_estimate_year = |population_estimate_rank = |population_census = |population_census_year = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_sq_mi = |population_density_rank = |GDP_PPP_year = |GDP_PPP = |GDP_PPP_rank = |GDP_PPP_per_capita = |GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = |sovereignty_type = [[Sovereignty]] |sovereignty_note = within the [[United States]] |established_event1 = Proposed |established_date1 = December 19, 2007 |established_event2 = Recognition |established_date2 = [[List of active separatist movements in North America#United States|None]] |HDI_year = |HDI = |HDI_rank = |HDI_category = |currency = [[United States dollar]] {{small|(''[[de facto]]'')}} |currency_code = |country_code = |cctld= |calling_code = |footnotes = }} The '''Republic of Lakotah''' or '''Lakotah''' is a [[List of active separatist movements in North America#United States|proposed independent republic]] in North America for the [[Lakota people]] and other people. Proposed by activist [[Russell Means]], the suggested territory would be enclaved by the borders of the [[United States]], covering thousands of square miles in [[North Dakota]], [[South Dakota]], [[Nebraska]], [[Wyoming]], and [[Montana]]. These proposed borders are those of the [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1851)|1851 Treaty of Fort Laramie]] between the [[Federal government of the United States|United States government]] and the [[Lakota people|Lakota]]. These lands are now occupied by [[Indian reservation]]s and non-Native settlements. None of the existing Lakota tribal governments support the proposed republic, and they were not consulted about the proposal.{{cite news |url=http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2008/01/04/withdrawal-us-treaties-enjoys-little-support-tribal-leaders-79806 |title=Withdrawal from US treaties enjoys little support from tribal leaders |author=Gale Courey Toensing |publisher=[[Indian Country Today]] |date=2008-01-04 |accessdate=2016-03-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160504091145/http://indiancountrytodaymedianetwork.com/2008/01/04/withdrawal-us-treaties-enjoys-little-support-tribal-leaders-79806 |archive-date=2016-05-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://www.dailykos.com/story/2007/12/23/425848/- ''Lakota Sioux Have NOT Withdrawn From the US]''; in [[The Daily Kos]]; December 23, 2007; accessed March 28, 2016 ==Background== Four [[activism|activists]], calling themselves the Lakota Freedom Delegation, traveled to [[Washington, D.C.]], on December 17, 2007, and delivered a [[Wikisource:Republic of Lakotah declaration of independence|statement]] declaring that they were, "withdrawing from the treaties their ancestors signed with the U.S." and "setting up their own independent nation." Reasons cited included that "the federal government has failed to abide by 33 treaties that promised land, health care, education and other services." Their leader was [[Russell Means]], one of the prominent members of the [[American Indian Movement]] in the late 1960s and 1970s.{{cite web |url= http://indianz.com/News/2007/006449.asp |title=Lakota Freedom Delegation withdraws from US |author= |publisher=indianz.com |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=September 27, 2016}} The Lakota Freedom Delegation stated that they did not recognize [[tribal council|tribal governments]] or presidents as recognized by the United States [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]], sometimes referring to these groups as "[[Collaborationism|stay-by-the-fort Indians]]".{{cite web |url=http://www.kumeyaay.com/kumeyaay-news/news-archive/1576-delegates-announce-pullout-from-us-treaties.html |title=Delegates announce pullout from U.S. treaties |author=Jerry Reynolds |publisher=Indian Country Today |date=December 18, 2007 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}} Nor did any tribal governments, elected by the tribal people themselves, recognize the Republic of Lakotah. ==Territory, demographics, and economics== The proposed boundaries of Lakotah are the [[Yellowstone River]] to the north, the [[North Platte River]] to the south, the [[Missouri River]] to the east and an irregular line marking the west.{{cite web |url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/map.html |title=Map |publisher=Republic of Lakotah |accessdate=2008-01-02 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105083334/http://www.republicoflakotah.com/map.html |archivedate=2008-01-05}}{{cite web |url=http://www.lakotaoyate.com/about.html |title=About |publisher=Lakota Oyate |accessdate=2008-01-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080115174839/http://www.lakotaoyate.com/about.html |archive-date=2008-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} These borders coincide with those set by the [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1851)|1851 Treaty of Fort Laramie]]: {{Blockquote|The territory of the [[Sioux]] or Dahcotah Nation, commencing the mouth of the [[White Earth River (North Dakota)|White Earth River]], on the [[Missouri River]]; thence in a southwesterly direction to the forks of the [[Platte River]]; thence up the north fork of the Platte River to a point known as the [[Red Butte, Wyoming|Red Buts]], or where the road leaves the river; thence along the range of mountains known as the [[Black Hills]], to the head-waters of [[Heart River (North Dakota)|Heart River]]; thence down Heart River to its mouth; and thence down the Missouri River to the place of beginning.{{cite web |url=http://www.canku-luta.org/PineRidge/laramie_treaty.html |title=Treaty of Fort Laramie - 1851 |accessdate=2008-01-02}}}} By these claims, the largest city in Lakotah is [[Omaha, Nebraska]]. The boundaries also contain [[Rapid City, South Dakota]]; [[Mandan, North Dakota]]; [[Casper, Wyoming]]; [[Bellevue, Nebraska]]; and [[Mount Rushmore]]. In addition to containing all the Indian reservations of the Lakota people, the territory which the republic claims includes reservations inhabited by non-Lakota Siouan peoples (the [[Dakota people]] and their communities, the [[Winnebago Indian Reservation]] and the [[Omaha Indian Reservation]]), and part of one non-Sioux reservation (the [[Fort Berthold Indian Reservation]] in western North Dakota). Lakotah would also contain some of the [[Lowest-income counties in the United States|poorest counties in the United States]]. ==Activities== On January 1, 2008, the republic announced that it would file [[lien]]s on all U.S. government-held lands within their claimed borders;{{cite press release |url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/docs/noticeofliens.pdf |title=Notice to All Foreign Governments and Private Owners of Real Estate within the Republic of Lakotah |date=2008-01-01 |accessdate=2008-01-02 |format=PDF |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411181415/http://www.republicoflakotah.com/docs/noticeofliens.pdf |archive-date=2008-04-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }} however, the first round of liens, in an unnamed county in South Dakota, were rejected. Following this the group chose to concentrate on the [[Black Hills]].{{cite web | url=http://www.indymedia.org/en/2008/01/899372.shtml |title=Republic of Lakotah focuses on Black Hills |date=15 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-02}} In July 2008, Means announced that the Republic of Lakotah would be founding an all-Lakota "grand jury" to investigate corruption by U.S. government officials on the seven reservations in the republic's claimed territory.{{cite web |date=July 28, 2008 |publisher=Rapid City Journal |url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/articles/2008/07/28/news/local/doc488d2d87d0b09450038082.txt |accessdate=2008-07-28 |author=[[Andrea J. Cook]] |title=Republic of Lakotah investigating tribal corruption}} Means unsuccessfully ran for the presidency of the [[Oglala Sioux|Oglala Lakota]] several times; in the 2008 election he lost 1,918 to 2,277.{{cite web |publisher=Rapid City Journal |url=http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/article_6fe9794b-d21e-5b05-a7e6-93dc28489d40.html |title=OST inauguration set for Friday |author=Heidi Bell Gease |date=December 2, 2008 |accessdate=2010-11-21}} ==Politics and government== Citizenship in the proposed republic would be open to people of all [[Race (classification of human beings)|races]] and to any resident of the land Lakotah claims. The group said they planned to issue their own passports and driving licenses in the name of the proposed nation.{{cite news |title=Sitting Bull's tribe declares independence |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/12/21/windian121.xml |author=Catherine Elsworth |date=2007-12-26 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=2007-12-31 |location=London}} The group proposed that the nation be organized as a confederation that would respect the [[libertarianism|libertarian]] principles of ''[[Posse comitatus (common law)|posse comitatus]]'' and ''[[caveat emptor]]'', would offer "individual liberty through community rule," and would collect no nationwide taxes. However, individual communities within the proposed nation would be allowed to levy taxes with the consent of the taxed. [[Russell Means]] suggested that the proposed nation should not use [[fiat currency]] but instead adopt a [[gold standard]].[http://www.freetalklive.com/files/means.mp3 Russell Means interview] from December 26, 2007 on [[Free Talk Live]] Means has stated that this system of government is derived from the traditional Lakota government system. Means said, "we are going to implement how we lived prior to [[European colonization of the Americas|the Invasion]]. Each community will be a mini-state unto itself ... They will form the federation known as Lakotah."{{cite video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlIYGE3JRsA |title=Republic of Lakota |date=2008-03-03 |publisher=Republic of Lakotah, hosted on [[YouTube]] |accessdate=2008-01-03}} As of 2008, Russell Means identified himself as "Chief Facilitator" of a [[provisional government]] of the Republic of Lakotah. The four signatories of the Lakota Freedom Delegation's letter to the [[United States Department of State]] that announced withdrawal from the U.S. identified themselves by the title of "[[Big man (anthropology)|Itacan]] of Lakota" in a press release.{{cite press release |url=http://www.commondreams.org/news2007/1220-02.htm |title=Freedom! Lakota Sioux Indians Declare Sovereign Nation Status |date=2007-12-20 |publisher=Lakota Freedom Delegation |accessdate=2007-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231093051/http://www.commondreams.org/news2007/1220-02.htm |archivedate=2007-12-31 |df= }} Leaders of communities would be informally chosen by [[Elder (administrative title)|elders]] of the community. ===Government=== The following people identified themselves as members of the provisional government of Lakotah: * Russell Means, chief facilitator (died 2012){{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/obituaries/la-me-russell-means-20121023,0,1631667,full.story|title=Russell Means dies at 72|author=Dennis McLellan|publisher= Los Angeles Times|date=October 23, 2013|accessdate=October 19, 2013}} * Tegheya Kte, also called Garry Rowland (fully, Clarence Gary Anthony Rowland), facilitator{{cite web|url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/Rowland.html |title=REPORT |date=February 24, 2008 |accessdate=2008-03-05 |publisher=republicoflakotah.com |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329232624/http://www.republicoflakotah.com/Rowland.html |archivedate=2008-03-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }} * Phyllis Young, provisional government member The [[Capital (political)|capital]] of Lakotah was not announced. The Republic of Lakotah gave its provisional capital as [[Porcupine, South Dakota]] with hopes in the long run to move administration to near [[Rapid City, South Dakota]].{{cite web|url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/FAQ.html |title=FAQ |publisher=Republic of Lakotah |accessdate=2008-01-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110144957/http://www.republicoflakotah.com/FAQ.html |archivedate=2008-01-10 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Connections with other movements== [[Russell Means]] and [[Robert Robideau]] were both prominent in the [[American Indian Movement]] (AIM), and later in [[American Indian Movement#Ideological differences within AIM|AIM Autonomous]], with Means along with Tegheya Kte having taken part in the [[Wounded Knee incident]] and Robideau acquitted in a trial related to the [[Leonard Peltier#Aftermath|Leonard Peltier case]]. Tegheya Kte, meanwhile, led the [[Spotted Elk|Big Foot]] Riders in 2007,{{cite web |url=http://www.commondreams.org/news2007/1227-03.htm |title=Chief Big Foot Riders Return To Wounded Knee, "We Want To Be Free" |date=December 27, 2007 |publisher=commondreams.org}} while Phyllis Young is one of the founders of [[Women of All Red Nations]].{{cite book |last=Josephy |first=Alvin M. |author2=Joane Nagel |author3=Troy R. Johnson |title=Red Power: The American Indians' Fight for Freedom |publisher=Univ of Nebraska Press |year=1999 |location= |pages=51 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DreCFo6MrR8C&dq |doi= |id= |isbn=0-8032-2587-3}} ==Assertion of independence== The Lakota Freedom Delegation traveled to [[Washington, D.C.]] and contacted the State Department, announcing that the Lakota were unilaterally withdrawing from the several treaties with the United States government. The delegation presented a letter, dated December 17, 2007 and signed by longtime Indian activists [[Russell Means]], Garry Rowland, Duane Martin Sr. (aka ''Canupa Gluha Mani''), and Phyllis Young, which declared the Lakota to be "predecessor sovereign of [[Dakota Territory]]" and cited gross violations of the treaties between the Lakota and the United States as the immediate cause for withdrawal. The letter also invited the United States government to enter into negotiations with the newly declared entity, there identified only as "Lakotah". It threatened that if good-faith negotiations were not begun then "Lakotah will begin to administer [[lien]]s against [[real estate]] transactions within the five state area of Lakotah."{{cite press release |url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/2009/2007-lakotah-unilateral-withdrawal/ |title=Lakotah Unilateral Withdrawal from All Agreements and Treaties with the United States of America |date=2007-12-17 |publisher=Lakota Freedom Delegation}} The group also has pursued international recognition for Lakotah at the embassies of [[Venezuela]], [[Bolivia]], [[Chile]], and [[South Africa]] and has claimed that [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] and [[East Timor]] are "very interested" in Lakotah's declaration and that they expect recognition from [[Russia]]. Russell Means has made reference to [[Finland]] and [[Iceland]] as well.{{cite news |url=http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/articles/2007/12/20/news/local/doc476a99630633e335271152.txt |title=Lakota Sioux Secede From US, Declare Independence |author=Bill Harlan |publisher=[[Rapid City Journal]] |date=2007-12-20 |accessdate=2007-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090823081033/http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/articles/2007/12/20/news/local/doc476a99630633e335271152.txt |archivedate=2009-08-23 |df= }} ==Legal basis for independence== [[File:Sioux01.png|right|thumb|Traditional range of the Siouan peoples (dark green) and the current reservations (orange).]] Supporters of Lakotah argue that their assertion of sovereignty is entirely legal under "[[Natural law|Natural]], [[International law|International]] and [[United States law]]".{{cite web |url= http://www.republicoflakotah.com/media.htm |title=Media |publisher=Republic of Lakotah |accessdate=2007-12-31}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The group emphasizes that the Republic's establishment comes from a "withdrawal" from the United States, not a [[secession]]. They argue that as an Indian tribe in the United States, the Lakota people were already and always have been a sovereign nation as guaranteed under [[Article Six of the United States Constitution]], bound to the United States Federal Government by treaty. As such, the legal basis of such a state's independence is argued to be the Lakota nation's withdrawal from the [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1851)|1851]] and [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1868)|1868]] Treaties of [[Fort Laramie]], and the rejection of all United States federal laws, [[Executive order (United States)|executive order]]s, and other government acts since then, in particular rejecting the [[Major Crimes Act]], the [[Dawes Act|General Allotment Act]], the [[Indian Citizenship Act of 1924|Citizenship Act of 1924]], the [[Indian Reorganization Act]] of 1934, the [[Indian Claims Commission Act]], [[Public Law 280]] and the [[Termination Act]]. The group claims its authority to assert independence derives from a long period of discussion and preparation involving a number of traditional [[Tribal chief|chief]]s and [[tribal council]]s representing the following Indian reservations and communities: *[[Pine Ridge Indian Reservation]] *[[Porcupine, South Dakota]] *[[Kyle, South Dakota]] *[[Rosebud Indian Reservation]] *[[Lower Brule Indian Reservation]] *[[Cheyenne River Indian Reservation]] *[[Standing Rock Indian Reservation]] *[[Flandreau Indian Reservation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lakotaoyate.net/history.html |title=History |publisher=Lakota Oyate |accessdate=2008-01-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080313161731/http://www.lakotaoyate.net/history.html |archivedate=2008-03-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The group also claims the right to withdraw, on behalf of the Lakota people, from the Treaties of Fort Laramie as a consequence of the [[Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties]] and the [[Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]]. Members argue that the decision in the case of ''[[Lone Wolf v. Hitchcock]]'', [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 187|187 U.S. 553 (1903)]] shows that the United States Government does not adequately protect Indian rights. Means also cites the [[Enabling Act of 1889]], stating that clauses protecting Indian sovereignty on the lands comprising the states where the Lakota historically reside have been ignored. In a 15 January 2008 news release, the Republic of Lakotah proposed that independence from the United States might follow a [[Compact of Free Association]] and suggested that the independence process could resemble that of the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines|Philippines]], [[Palau]], the [[Federated States of Micronesia]] or the [[Marshall Islands]]. Russell Means also stated that he intended to treat the result of the 2008 Pine Ridge Reservation Presidential election, in which he was a candidate,{{cite web |url=http://www.russellmeansfreedom.com/ |title=Russell Means for President of Pine Ridge Sioux Indian Reservation |accessdate=2008-04-03}} as a "[[plebiscite]]/[[referendum]]" on Lakota independence.{{cite podcast |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f7SYMGyWdDk |title=Russell Means Freedom Part 1 |website=[[YouTube]] |host=[[Russell Means]] |date=April 2, 2008 |accessdate=2008-04-03}} ==Motivations for independence== Lakotah's founders cite the [[Oglala Sioux|Oglala]] 1974 Declaration of Continuing Independence: {{Blockquote|The United States of America has continually violated the independent Native Peoples of this continent by Executive action, Legislative fiat and Judicial decision. By its actions, the U.S. has denied all Native people their International Treaty rights, Treaty lands and basic human rights of freedom and sovereignty. This same U.S. Government, which fought to throw off the yoke of oppression and gain its own independence, has now reversed its role and become the oppressor of sovereign Native people.{{cite press release |url=http://www.treatycouncil.org/PDFs/DECLARATION_OF_CONTINUING_INDEPENDENCE.pdf |title=Declaration of Continuing Independence by the First International Indian Treaty Council at Standing Rock Indian Country June 1974 |date=June 1974 |format=PDF}}}} The groups cite several reasons for its assertion of sovereignty, all connected to what they refer to as the "[[Colonialism|colonial]] [[apartheid]]" of the reservation system in the United States. The group claims that control by the United States has led to massive unemployment, poverty and disease among the Lakota people and also alleges that 150 years of U.S. administration is responsible for the statistical poverty of Lakota lands. The group claims that withdrawal from the United States will reverse these problems, and help reestablish the [[Lakota language]] and culture.{{cite web |url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/why.htm |title=Why |publisher=Republic of Lakotah |accessdate=2007-12-31}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lakotaoyate.net/why.html |title=Why |publisher=Lakota Oyate |accessdate=2008-01-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080313155208/http://www.lakotaoyate.net/why.html |archivedate=2008-03-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The group also claims persistent violations by the United States of their treaties with the Lakota. [[File:Inyan-Kara.jpg|thumb|right|[[Inyan Kara Mountain|Inyan Kara]], in the [[Black Hills]] is a sacred mountain to the [[Lakota people|Lakota]].]] Another longstanding point of contention between the Lakota and the United States is the status of the [[Black Hills]] of South Dakota, which were part of [[Sioux]] reservation lands until they were taken without compensation by the US government and opened for gold mining following the collapse of the [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1868)]]. In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court decision ''[[United States v. Sioux Nation of Indians]]'' awarded $105 million to eight tribes of Sioux Indians as compensation ($17.1 million for the market value of the land in 1877 and $88 million in 5% per annum simple interest between 1877 and 1980),{{cite web |url=http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=CASE&court=US&vol=448&page=371 |title= UNITED STATES v. SIOUX NATION OF INDIANS, 448 U.S. 371 (1980) |publisher=FindLaw |accessdate=2008-06-13}}{{cite web |date=December 19, 2007 |publisher=Rapid City Journal |url=http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/news/local/article_43e36124-43fc-5e9d-b102-65584e665dda.html |accessdate=2007-12-19 |author=[[Bill Harlan]] |title=Lakota group secedes from U.S.}} but the court did not award land. The tribal governments of the Lakota have refused the settlement.{{cite web |url=http://worldmeets.us/lemonde0000166.shtml |title=Sioux Indians of Lakota Tribe Tell State Dept. of Succession |publisher=Le Monde |accessdate=2008-04-29}} ==Reactions== The extent of popular support among the Lakota people for independence is unclear. Russell Means and Canupa Gluha Mani have claimed that some 13,000 Lakota, including 77% of the population of Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, have shown support for the Republic of Lakotah, and that the eight-member delegation which traveled to Washington, D.C. was only a portion of some 77 tribal elders and activists taking part in the movement.{{cite interview |url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/hrr/2007/12/22/Russell-Means- |date=2007-12-22 |accessdate=2008-01-05 |work=Heading Right |interviewer=Ed Morissey |last=Means |first=Russell |subjectlink=Russell Means |publisher=[[Blogtalkradio]]}}{{cite podcast |url=http://memes.org/audio-interview-canupa-gluha-mani-lakota-freedom-delegation |title=Interview with Canupa Gluha Mani - Lakota Freedom Delegation |date=2007-12-25 |host=Juxtaposeur |website=[http://memes.org Mind Viruses]}} However, ''[[Rapid City Journal]]'' reporter Bill Harlan reported on his [[blog]] that "most folks I talk to hadn't heard about the declaration. The ones who had heard the news, to a person, did not want to talk about it on the record."{{cite web |url=http://www.rapidcityjournal.com/politicalblog/?p=2381 |title=Lakota Nation: no taxes! |author=Bill Harlan |publisher=Mount Blogmore, the ''[[Rapid City Journal]]'' Politlcal Blog |date=2007-12-21 |accessdate=2008-01-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The ''Journal'' has also noted that "there were no tribal presidents in the group which made the announcement, no one from the top ranks of any of the Lakota Sioux tribes."{{cite web |url=http://rapidcityjournal.com/blogs/editor/?p=339 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713152917/http://rapidcityjournal.com/blogs/editor/?p=339 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-13 |author=Mikel LeFort |title=Lakota announcement: Where does it go? |publisher=Typos and Tribulations: Behind the headlines with a ''[[Rapid City Journal]]'' editor |date=2007-01-20 |accessdate=2008-01-01}} Nanwica Kciji, an [[Oglala Lakota]] and first president of the Native American Journalists Association, has also discredited the December 2007 developments, arguing that the Lakotah Freedom Delegation "never considered that treaties are made between nations and not individuals."{{cite news |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/tim-giago/catering-to-that-10-perce_b_79241.html |title=Catering to That 10 Percent That Love to be Mascots |accessdate=2008-01-07 |author=Tim Giago |work=Huffington Post}} The [[Alaskan Independence Party]], in an announcement dated December 21, 2007, "applauded" the independent Lakota nation and granted it "full recognition".{{cite web |url=http://www.akip.org/lakota.html |author=[[Lynette Clark]] |title=Alaskan Independence Party |date=2007-12-21 |accessdate=2008-01-18}} The secessionist movement [[Second Vermont Republic]] has also announced its support, and encouraged other American Indian groups to similarly declare independence from the United States.{{cite web |url=http://vermontrepublic.org/news_events/lakota_independence_resolution |title=Lakota Independence Resolution |date=15 January 2008 |accessdate=2008-01-23 |publisher=[[Second Vermont Republic]]}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} ===Response from recognized Native American governments=== Rodney Bordeaux, chairman of the [[Brulé|Rosebud Sioux]], said that [[Rosebud Indian Reservation]] has no interest in joining the Republic of Lakotah and said that the Lakota Freedom Delegation never presented their plan to the tribal council.{{cite news |url=http://www.argusleader.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071220/NEWS/712200347 |title=Lakota group pushes for new nation |author=Faith Bremner |publisher=[[Argus Leader]] |date=2007-12-20 |accessdate=2007-12-31}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Bordeaux stated that the group does not represent the Lakota people nor the support of the elected tribal governments. However, he did say that Russell Means "made some good points". Joseph Brings Plenty, chairman of the [[Cheyenne River Lakota]], agreed that the Lakota Freedom Delegation "are not representative of the nation I represent" but would not say whether he agreed or disagreed with their goals and message, noting some value in the group's actions in raising awareness for the history of the Lakota people. ===International response=== Internationally, according to Russell Means, [[Venezuela]]'s ambassador to the United States has stated to the group that his country cannot recognize Lakotah's independence based on Venezuela's interpretation of what the Lakotah Freedom Delegation is doing. In February 2008, the Lakotah Freedom Delegation (including Means) handed over a formal petition, asking for recognition of the Republic of Lakotah, to the embassies of [[Russia]], [[Serbia]], [[Bolivia]], [[Venezuela]], the [[Republic of South Africa]], [[Ireland]], [[France]], [[Nicaragua]], [[East Timor]], [[Chile]], [[Turkey]], [[India]], [[Finland]], [[Iceland]] and [[Uruguay]]. The text of the petition is available online.{{Cite web |url=http://www.republicoflakotah.com/docs/Petition.pdf |title=untitled |access-date=2008-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411181412/http://www.republicoflakotah.com/docs/Petition.pdf |archive-date=2008-04-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ===U.S. government response=== The [[United States Department of State]] referred queries on the subject of Lakotah to the [[United States Department of the Interior]], which oversees the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]]."For your query, we will refer you to the Department of the Interior. This is not a State Department issue." [[Kirsten Petree]], Director, Office of Media Affairs, U.S. Department of State, private communication with [[wikinews:Lakota activists declare secession from US|Wikinews]] (December 21, 2007) Gary Garrison of the BIA said that the group's withdrawal "doesn't mean anything". "These are not legitimate tribal governments elected by the people ... when they begin the process of violating other people's rights, breaking the law, they're going to end up like all the other groups that have declared themselves independent — usually getting arrested and being put in jail." Regarding the government response, or lack thereof, Russell Means stated that, "I don't expect the federal government to do anything. I don't believe they even know what to do." ==See also== * [[Great Sioux Reservation]] * [[Great Sioux Nation]] * [[Siouxland]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Wikinewshas |related stories| *[[wikinews:Lakota activists declare secession from US|Lakota activists declare secession from US]] *[[wikinews:Lakota Freedom Delegation says spokesman Russell Means 'hijacked' organization|Lakota Freedom Delegation says spokesman Russell Means 'hijacked' organization]] *[[wikinews:Canupa Gluha Mani speaks about Lakota Oyate, Lakota freedom|Canupa Gluha Mani speaks about Lakota Oyate, Lakota freedom]] *[[wikinews:'No treaty withdrawal', says Lakota elder|'No treaty withdrawal', says Lakota elder]]}} *[http://www.republicoflakotah.com/ Republic of Lakotah] *{{YouTube|Hm0JIgVHypQ|Russell Means discussing the Republic of Lakotah}} *[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/06/24/AR2008062401162.html?nav=rss_email/components "Ways and Means" By Bill Donahue, Washington Post] {{DEFAULTSORT:Republic Of Lakotah}} [[Category:Independence movements|Lakotah]] [[Category:Lakota]] [[Category:Native American nationalism]] [[Category:Proposed countries]] [[Category:Separatism in the United States]]

[[Stanisław Salaterski]]
[[Leszek Leszkiewicz]] |emeritus_bishops = [[Władysław Bobowski]] }} The '''[[Diocese]] of [[Tarnów]]''' is a [[Roman Catholic]] diocese in [[Poland]]. According to Church statistics, it is the most religious diocese in Poland, with 72.5% weekly Mass attendance.[http://goscniedzielny.wiara.pl/index.php?grupa=6&art=1184589442&dzi=1104785534&katg= Tygodnik Katolicki - Gość Niedzielny - Wydanie Internetowe] [[Image:A. Jeż.jpg|thumb|200px|left| Bishop Jeż]] == References == {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{coord|50.0131|N|20.9871|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tarnow}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Tarnów]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Infobox organization |name = |logo = [[File:Roots & Shoots Logo.jpg|centre|200px]] ||type = [[Non-profit Organization]] |founded_date = {{start date and age|1991}} |founder = [[Jane Goodall]]{{cite web |url = http://www.janegoodall.org/programs/youth |title = Roots & Shoots |publisher = [[Jane Goodall Institute]]}} |location_country = [[Vienna, Virginia]], [[United States|U.S.]] |area_served = World wide |origins = [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]] | key_people =
* [[Jane Goodall]] (Founder) * Erin Viera-Orr (Associate Vice President Roots & Shoots)
* Adrienne Bermingham (Program Coordinator) * Stephanie Keller (Education Projects Manager) * Kamilah Martin (Associate Director) * Hope Martinez (Youth Leadership Program Manager) * Emily Rhodes (Education Manager) |focus = [[Environmentalism]], [[Conservation biology|Conservation]], [[Humanitarianism]] |method = Community action, service projects, youth-led campaigns, networking youth |revenue = |num_volunteers = |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = Knowledge, Compassion, Action |homepage = [http://rootsandshoots.org// http://rootsandshoots.org/] |dissolved = |footnotes = }} '''Roots & Shoots''' was founded by [[Jane Goodall]], DBE in 1991, with the goal of bringing together youth from preschool to university age to work on environmental, conservation and humanitarian issues.{{cite web |url = https://rwpzoo.org/159/roots-shoots |title = Roots & Shoots |publisher = [[Roger Williams Park Zoo]] }} The organization has local chapters in over 140 countries{{cite web |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sierra-club/jane-goodall-sowing-seeds_b_3910289.html |title = Jane Goodall: Sowing 'Seeds of Hope' |publisher = [[Huffington Post]] }} with over 8000 local groups worldwide{{cite web |url = |title = Jane Goodall, Roots & Shoots|publisher = World Peace Emerging Blog}} that involve nearly 150,000{{cite web |url = https://www.rootsandshoots.org/about|title = Jane Goodall's Roots & Shoots|publisher = Roots & Shoots}} youth. Many of the chapters operate through schools and other organizations. Participants are encouraged to identify and work on problems in their own communities affecting people, animals, or the environment.{{cite news | author = | title =Jane Goodall toasts 20 years of "Roots and Shoots" | url =https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-janegoodall-idUSTRE71I3JF20110219 | newspaper =[[Reuters]] | location = | date = | access-date = }} [[Charity Navigator]], has awarded Roots & Shoots and its parent non-profit organization, the [[Jane Goodall Institute]], its highest four star rating for [[accountability]] and transparency with 78.1% of its expenses going directly to programs.{{cite web |url = http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=3919#.UlkD72Q374Y |title = Jane Goodall Institute |publisher = Charity Navigator }} ==Origin== Roots & Shoots was founded in 1991, when Dr. Goodall started to give talks at local schools in [[Tanzania]]. A group of 12 of her students selected by their classmates met with her at her home to discuss their local environmental concerns and to figure out what they could do.{{Cite web|title = Jane Goodall’s Roots & Shoots - The Jane Goodall Institute|url = http://www.janegoodall.org/what-we-do/roots-and-shoots/|website = The Jane Goodall Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-30|language = en}} These 12 students became the first members of Roots & Shoots, and the organization grew from there. Of the original 12 students, one went on to serve as the minister of environment for Tanzania and another became the Roots & Shoots' national director for Tanzania.{{cite web |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/19/us-janegoodall-idUSTRE71I3JF20110219 |title = Jane Goodall toasts 20 years of "Roots and Shoots" |publisher = [[Reuters]] }} ==Curricula== {{ad|date=August 2018}} The Roots & Shoots curriculum is a learning program for teachers and other community leaders to use with students and young people to help them develop environmental, conservationist and humanitarian programs to improve their communities. Through service projects, students develop a sense of service and leadership in their own communities. The curriculums are split into elementary, middle and high school lesson plans. The program encourages young people to create projects that support campaigns. Roots & Shoots provides resources about how to integrate these projects into the local community.{{cite web |url = http://www.pearsonfoundation.org/janegoodall/ |title = Curriculum-Based Service Learning Program |publisher = Pearson Foundation |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130716145809/http://www.pearsonfoundation.org/janegoodall/ |archivedate = 2013-07-16 |df = }} One major tenant of the Roots & Shoots model is to use science and technology to map out community needs in order to find the places in a community where a campaign or service projects can help people, animals, or the environment.{{Cite web|title = Get Started! {{!}} Roots & Shoots|url = http://www.rootsandshoots.org/content/get-started|website = www.rootsandshoots.org|accessdate = 2015-10-30}} Roots & Shoots also uses technology to train club leaders through its massive open online course, Turning Learners into Leaders: Empowering Youth Through Service Innovation.{{Cite web|title = Roots & Shoots Online Course {{!}} Roots & Shoots|url = http://www.rootsandshoots.org/onlinecourse|website = www.rootsandshoots.org|accessdate = 2015-10-30}} The free professional development course provides community leaders with training on community mapping, fostering leadership in young people, collaborating with community stakeholders, and guiding young leaders towards practical solutions for community campaigns. ==Branches== There are active Roots & Shoots branches in at least 27 countries, with offices in Abu Dhabi, Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, China, Canada, Columbia, Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Italy, Kenya, Puerto Rico, Nepal, New Zealand, Singapore, South Africa, Spain, Taiwan, Tanzania, Uganda, the United Kingdom, and the United States.{{Cite web|title = Global Offices - The Jane Goodall Institute|url = http://www.janegoodall.org/who-we-are/contact/global-offices/|website = The Jane Goodall Institute|accessdate = 2015-10-30|language = en}} ===China=== [[China]] has three main Roots & Shoots branches in [[Beijing]], [[Shanghai]], and [[Chengdu]] that supports over 600 primarily school groups.{{cite web |url = http://www.jgi-shanghai.org/index.php/english/about_r_s/rands-in-china/ |title = Roots & Shoots offices in China |publisher = Shanghai Roots & Shoots |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131016090023/http://www.jgi-shanghai.org/index.php/english/about_r_s/rands-in-china/ |archivedate = 2013-10-16 |df = }} ===United States=== ====Tulsa, Oklahoma==== [[Riverfield Country Day School]]{{ |url = http://www.riverfield.org |title = Riverfield Country Day School}} in Tulsa has implemented the Roots & Shoots program. ====Tucson, Arizona==== [[Empire High School]]{{ |url = http://ehs.vail.k12.az.us/ |title = Empire High School}} in Tucson has also implemented the Roots & Shoots program. ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== * [http://rootsandshoots.org/ Roots & Shoots] * [http://www.janegoodall.org/ Jane Goodall Institute] {{DEFAULTSORT:Roots and Shoots}} [[Category:Jane Goodall]] [[Category:Conservation organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Environmental organizations based in Virginia]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1991]] [[Category:Wildlife conservation organizations]] [[Category:1991 establishments in the United States]]

Maluku}} |subdivision_type2 = |subdivision_name2 = |subdivision_type3 = [[Capital (political)|Capital]] |subdivision_name3 =[[Labuha]] |government_type = |leader_title = Regent |leader_name = Bahrain |timezone = [[Time in Indonesia|IEST]] |utc_offset = +9 |timezone_DST = |utc_offset_DST = |coordinates = {{coord|0.3955|S|127.9083|E|source:wikidata|display=title,inline}} |elevation_m = |elevation_ft = |postal_code_type = |postal_code = |area_code_type = [[Telephone numbers in Indonesia|Area code]] |area_code = (+62) 927 |website = *{{url|halselkab.go.id}} *{{url|halmaheraselatankab.go.id}} |footnotes = }} '''South Halmahera Regency''' ({{lang-id|Kabupaten Halmahera Selatan}}) is a [[Regencies of Indonesia|regency]] of [[North Maluku]] Province, [[Indonesia]]. It lies partly on [[Halmahera]] Island and partly on smaller islands to the west and south of Halmahera. It covers a land area of 8,148.90 sq.km, and at the 2010 Census it had a population of 198,911 people;Biro Pusat Statistik, Jakarta, 2011. the latest official estimate (as at January 2014) was 218,738. The capital lies at [[Labuha]] on Bacan Island. ==Islands== Besides the southern part of Halmahera Island, the Regency includes a number of archipelagoes and islands. Among them: * [[Obi Islands]], including [[Obira]] (main), Bisa, Obilatu and other small islands, comprising in all five ''kecamatan'' with 41,455 people at the 2010 census. * [[Bacan Islands]], including: ** Bacan Island itself, comprising 7 ''kecamatan'' with 60,742 people ** Batan Lomang Island, comprising 1 ''kecamatan'' with 6,177 people ** [[Mandioli]], comprising 2 ''kecamatan'' with 8,788 people ** [[Kasiruta]], comprising 2 ''kecamatan'' with 8,368 people * [[Kayoa]] Group, comprising 4 ''kecamatan'' with 20,176 people * [[Makian]], comprising 2 ''kecamatan'' with 12,394 people * Joronga Islands, comprising 1 ''kecamatan'' with 5,264 people, including the southern tip of Halmahera Island * the southern peninsula of [[Halmahera]] Island (the area is known as Gane), comprising 6 ''kecamatan'' with 35,547 people.http://www.halmaheraselatankab.go.id/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=152:penduduk-halsel&catid=62:penduduk&Itemid=41 == Administration == The regency is divided into thirty [[Districts of Indonesia|districts]] (''kecamatan''), tabulated below with their areas and their 2010 Census populations. {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! provincial governor [[Abdul Ghani Kasuba]] as a region for tourism development.[https://en.tempo.co/read/news/2017/05/21/199877340/Widi-Islands-to-be-the-Future-of-North-Maluku-Tourism Widi Islands to be the Future of North Maluku Tourism]. [[Tempo (Indonesian magazine)|Tempo]], 21 May 2017. Accessed 18 September 2017. The Widi International Fishing Tournament was founded for this purpose.Aria Cindyara, [http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/112373/n-maluku-to-boost-maritime-sector-through-fishing-tourism N Maluku to boost maritime sector through fishing tourism]. [[Antara (news agency)|Antara]], 24 August 2017. Accessed 30 August 2017. Kasuba also successfully negotiated for the China-based Jinchun Group to build a nine-trillion rupiah nickel smelter in the Obi Islands.[http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/105701/chinas-jinchun-to-in-vest-rp9-trillion-in-north-maluku China`s Jinchun to in vest Rp9 trillion in North Maluku]. Antara, 16 July 2016. Accessed 18 September 2017. ==References== {{reflist}} {{North Maluku}} [[Category:Regencies of North Maluku]] [[Category:Halmahera]] {{Maluku-geo-stub}}

It is a Kazakhstani-Japanese co-production and is directed by [[Erlan Nurmuhambetov]] and [[Shinju Sano]].{{cite book |title=International Film Guide 2012 |first=Ian Hayden |last=Smith |year= 2012 |isbn= 978-1908215017 |page= 159}}{{cite web|url=http://2012.tiff-jp.net/en/lineup/works.php?id=148 |title=The First Rains of Spring |accessdate=7 September 2012 |work=tiff}} The film won the Grand Prix at the [[International Eurasia Film Festival|Eurasia Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ocamagazine.com/japanese-kazakh-film-wins-grand-prix-at-eurasia-film-festival |title=Japanese-Kazakh film wins Grand Prix at Eurasia film festival |accessdate=7 September 2012 |work=ocamagazine}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|2075333|The First Rains of Spring}} {{DEFAULTSORT:First Rains Of Spring}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Kazakhstani films]] [[Category:Japanese films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] {{Kazakhstan-film-stub}} {{2010s-Japan-film-stub}}

"Runaway" # "Ain't nobody like be" # "Summerfiled" # "I'll be gone tomorrow!" # "Worries me" # "Quick loving hearts" # "I got (every thing but you)" # "Close to the ground" # "Sunshower" # "Runaway" (outro) == Personnel == * [[Daniel Romano]] – Guitar, back voc, synth, drums, co – producer * Lars Erik Larsen – Bass, back voc, co – producer * Kjetil Johan Jakobsen – drums, back voc * [[Martin Windstad]] – Percussion * [[David Wallumrød]] – Hammond Organ A-100, Piano * [[Amund Maarud]] – guitar * [[Bendik Brænne]] – vocals, piano, flute, engineer, producer, piano * Eivind Solheim – trumpet * Sindre Blostrupmoen – trumpet * [[Mari Persen]] – strings * [[Dan Weston]] – mix * [[Greg Calbi]] – mastering == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{cite web|url=http://www.itromso.no/feedback/anmeldelser/2017/09/01/En-orgie-av-skamløs-fantasi-15236323.ece|title=En orgie av skamløs fantasi|website=itromso.no|accessdate=2017-09-04}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B074JTF3YD|website=amazon.com|title=Amazon.com: The last great country swindle: Bendik Brænne: MP3 Downloads|accessdate=2017-09-04}} * {{cite web|url=https://shop.klicktrack.com/506772|website=shop.klicktrack.com|title=Klicktrack Music Store : The last great country swindle|accessdate=2017-09-04}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Last Great Country Swindle}} [[Category:2017 albums]] [[Category:Bendik Brænne albums]] {{Norway-stub}} {{2010s-country-album-stub}}

page.title: The Old Man and the Medal

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Old Man and the Medal''' ({{lang|fr|Le vieux nègre et la médaille}}) ''is a 1956 post colonial novel by Cameroonian diplomat and writer [[Ferdinand Oyono]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = OGUNSANWO | first = OLATUBOSUN | date = 1986-01-01 | title = The Narrative Voice in Two Novels of Ferdinand Oyono | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00138398608690832 | journal = English Studies in Africa | volume = 29 | issue = 2 | pages = 97–120 | doi = 10.1080/00138398608690832 | issn = 0013-8398 }}</ref> The novel was translated into English and republished in 1967 in the influential [[Heinemann African Writers Series]].
When reflecting on the novel, in Oyono's obituary, ''[[The Guardian]]'' writer [[Shola Adenekan]] described the novel as "evoking the deep sense of disillusionment felt by those Africans who were committed to the west, yet rejected by their colonial masters."<ref>{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/30/cameroon | title = Ferdinand Oyono obituary | last = Adenekan | first = Shola | date = 2010-06-30 | newspaper = The Guardian | language = en-GB | issn = 0261-3077 | access-date = 2016-02-26 }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Old Man and the Medal}} [[Category:1956 novels]] [[Category:Cameroonian novels]] [[Category:African Writers Series]] [[Category:French-language novels]]
